name: Go
title: This cheat sheet provided basic syntax and methods to help you using [Go](https://go.dev/).

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: This cheat sheet provided basic syntax and methods to help you using [Go](https://go.dev/).

cards.title: hello.go
hello.go
cards.body:
```shell script
$ go run hello.go
Hello, world!

cards.title: hello.go
cards.code:
Or try it out in the [Go repl](https://repl.it/languages/go)

### Variables

```go
var s1 string
s1 = "Learn Go!"

// declare multiple variables at once
var b, c int = 1, 2
var d = true

cards.title: hello.go
cards.code:
s1 := "Learn Go!"        // string
b, c := 1, 2             // int
d := true                // bool

cards.title: Functions
Comments
If statement
Strings
cards.code:
s1 := "Hello" + "World"

s2 := `A "raw" string literal
can include line breaks.`

// Outputs: 10
fmt.Println(len(s1))

// Outputs: Hello
fmt.Println(string(s1[0:5]))

cards.title: Numbers
cards.code:
num := 3         // int
num := 3.        // float64
num := 3 + 4i    // complex128
num := byte('a') // byte (alias: uint8)

var u uint = 7        // uint (unsigned)
var p float32 = 22.7  // 32-bit float

cards.title: Numbers
cards.code:
x := 5
x++
fmt.Println("x + 4 =", x + 4)
fmt.Println("x * 4 =", x * 4)

cards.title: Booleans
cards.code:
isTrue   := true
isFalse  := false

cards.title: Booleans
cards.code:
fmt.Println(true && true)   // true
fmt.Println(true && false)  // false
fmt.Println(true || true)   // true
fmt.Println(true || false)  // true
fmt.Println(!true)          // false

cards.title: Arrays
Arrays
cards.code:
var a [2]string
a[0] = "Hello"
a[1] = "World"

fmt.Println(a[0], a[1]) //=> Hello World
fmt.Println(a)   // => [Hello World]

cards.title: Arrays
Pointers
Pointers
Pointers
cards.code:
a := new(int)
*a = 234

cards.title: Slices
cards.code:
s := make([]string, 3)
s[0] = "a"
s[1] = "b"
s = append(s, "d")
s = append(s, "e", "f")

fmt.Println(s)
fmt.Println(s[1])
fmt.Println(len(s))
fmt.Println(s[1:3])

slice := []int{2, 3, 4}

cards.title: Constants
cards.code:
const s string = "constant"
const Phi = 1.618
const n = 500000000
const d = 3e20 / n
fmt.Println(d)

cards.title: Type conversions
cards.code:
i := 90
f := float64(i)
u := uint(i)

// Will be equal to the character Z
s := string(i)

cards.title: Type conversions
cards.code:
i := 90

// need import "strconv"
s := strconv.Itoa(i)
fmt.Println(s) // Outputs: 90

cards.title: Strings function
fmt.Printf
cards.code:
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
)

type point struct {
	x, y int
}

func main() {
	p := point{1, 2}
	fmt.Printf("%v\n", p)                        // => {1 2}
	fmt.Printf("%+v\n", p)                       // => {x:1 y:2}
	fmt.Printf("%#v\n", p)                       // => main.point{x:1, y:2}
	fmt.Printf("%T\n", p)                        // => main.point
	fmt.Printf("%t\n", true)                     // => TRUE
	fmt.Printf("%d\n", 123)                      // => 123
	fmt.Printf("%b\n", 14)                       // => 1110
	fmt.Printf("%c\n", 33)                       // => !
	fmt.Printf("%x\n", 456)                      // => 1c8
	fmt.Printf("%f\n", 78.9)                     // => 78.9
	fmt.Printf("%e\n", 123400000.0)              // => 1.23E+08
	fmt.Printf("%E\n", 123400000.0)              // => 1.23E+08
	fmt.Printf("%s\n", "\"string\"")             // => "string"
	fmt.Printf("%q\n", "\"string\"")             // => "\"string\""
	fmt.Printf("%x\n", "hex this")               // => 6.86578E+15
	fmt.Printf("%p\n", &p)                       // => 0xc00002c040
	fmt.Printf("|%6d|%6d|\n", 12, 345)           // => |    12|   345|
	fmt.Printf("|%6.2f|%6.2f|\n", 1.2, 3.45)     // => |  1.20|  3.45|
	fmt.Printf("|%-6.2f|%-6.2f|\n", 1.2, 3.45)   // => |1.20  |3.45  |
	fmt.Printf("|%6s|%6s|\n", "foo", "b")        // => |   foo|     b|
	fmt.Printf("|%-6s|%-6s|\n", "foo", "b")      // => |foo   |b     |

	s := fmt.Sprintf("a %s", "string")
	fmt.Println(s)

	fmt.Fprintf(os.Stderr, "an %s\n", "error")
}

cards.title: Conditional
Statements in if
Statements in if
Switch
cards.body:
```go {.wrap}
x := 42.0
switch x {
case 0:
case 1, 2:
fmt.Println("Multiple matches")
case 42:   // Don't "fall through".
fmt.Println("reached")
case 43:
fmt.Println("Unreached")
default:
fmt.Println("Optional")
}

cards.title: Switch
For-Range loop
For-Range loop
cards.code:
### While loop

```go
i := 1
for i <= 3 {
    fmt.Println(i)
    i++
}

cards.title: Continue keyword
Break keyword
Defining
Literals
Literals
cards.body: You can also put field names.

cards.title: Maps
cards.code:
m := make(map[string]int)
m["k1"] = 7
m["k2"] = 13
fmt.Println(m) // => map[k1:7 k2:13]

v1 := m["k1"]
fmt.Println(v1)     // => 7
fmt.Println(len(m)) // => 2

delete(m, "k2")
fmt.Println(m) // => map[k1:7]

_, prs := m["k2"]
fmt.Println(prs) // => false

n := map[string]int{"foo": 1, "bar": 2}
fmt.Println(n) // => map[bar:2 foo:1]

cards.title: Pointers to structs
cards.code:
v := &Vertex{1, 2}
v.X = 2

cards.title: Pointers to structs
cards.body: Doing `v.X` is the same as doing `(*v).X`, when `v` is a pointer.

cards.title: Multiple arguments
Multiple return
Function literals
Naked returns
cards.code:
func split(sum int) (x, y int) {
  x = sum * 4 / 9
  y = sum - x
  return
}

x, y := split(17)
fmt.Println(x)   // => 7
fmt.Println(y)   // => 10

cards.title: Naked returns
cards.body: Note that using naked returns hurts readability.
